image:image.image:title: Blog - Manipulating single atoms with an electron beam
image:image.image:caption: An electron beam focused on a carbon atom next to a silicon impurity atom can controllably make it jump to where the beam was placed. Step by step this allows the silicon to be moved with atomic precision around a hexagonal path. (CC-BY, Toma Susi / University of Vienna.)

image:image.image:title: Bodypainting - The New Path

image:image.image:title: Density functional theory
image:image.image:caption: To simulate core level spectra, we can introduce a core hole on one of the atoms. The hole gets screened very efficiently in a metallic system such as graphene, resulting in an oscillating electron density difference compared to the ground state. The energy difference between the excited and ground states is an estimate of the core level binding energy.

image:image.image:title: Electron energy loss spectroscopy
image:image.image:caption: The inset images show energy ranges corresponding to the P L-edge and C K-edge mapped over a single phosphorus dopant implanted into graphene. (doi:10.1088/2053-1583/aa5e78

image:image.image:title: Manipulating atoms
image:image.image:caption: A silicon atom embedded in the graphene lattice shows bright in the STEM MAADF scattering contrast. While imaging the area, the silicon atom "jumps" to the next lattice site, with no atoms lost from the structure. The mechanism is explained by atomistic simulations which reveal the complex out-of-plane dynamics responsible for the Si-C bond inversion.

image:image.image:title: Heteroatom doping
image:image.image:caption: An atomistic model of a single-walled carbon nanotube doped with nitrogen heteroatoms (shown in green). Depending on their covalent radius and valence electronic structure, the dopants can bond in different configurations. These can have quite different effects on the properties of the host material, making the identification of bonding one of the crucial research questions.
